content.subtitle: This piece at Nielsen Norman describes it as fake minimalism:

paragraphs.name: 4e94
paragraphs.text: It is a serious problem that younger designers may not notice until they begin to age and their own eyesight begins to decline. It is particularly tough for the bifocal/trifocal crowd which we are all destined to become as we read tinier and tinier type on small devices or on devices with significant glare (Hey Apple, matted screens are better for my eyes than retina screens.)

ae5600db64be.title: It is a serious problem that younger designers may not notice until they begin to age and their own…

paragraphs.name: 26d5
paragraphs.text: There are many other typographic tools at your disposal here — font size and weight specifically, as well as varying typeface choice. These too can be overdone, but you can establish a visual hierarchy without throwing away a huge part of the colour gamut. I understand that motivation, but when most of the text on the page is a pallid spindly shadow of its former self you are doing it wrong.

paragraphs.text: I find it a bit ironic that the font used in this story also is gray. Uneven characters looks ugly and unappealing.

virtuals.subtitle: I thought my eyesight was beginning to go. It turns out, I’m suffering from design.

paragraphs.name: e618
paragraphs.text: How the Web Became Unreadable
I thought my eyesight was beginning to go. It turns out, I’m suffering…

content.subtitle: I thought my eyesight was beginning to go. It turns out, I’m suffering from design.

paragraphs.name: ce3e
paragraphs.text:
Thanks for writing this. You know I’ve been bitching about it since the 90s. What I don’t understand is the motivation.
I wonder if there’s a way we could sample the web over time to see if it’s getting better or worse? say write a script that checks the top 100 sites CSS changes. Or even better, extract the data from the internet archive?

paragraphs.name: 6b12
paragraphs.text: My plea to designers and software engineers: Ignore the fads and go back to the typographic principles of print — keep your type black, and vary weight and font instead of grayness. You’ll be making things better for people who read on smaller, dimmer screens, even if their eyes aren’t aging like mine. It may not be trendy, but it’s time to consider who is being left out by the web’s aesthetic.

paragraphs.name: 18a6
paragraphs.text: When you build a site and ignore what happens afterwards — when the values entered in code are translated into brightness and contrast depending on the settings of a physical screen — you’re avoiding the experience that you create. And when you design in perfect settings, with big, contrast-rich monitors, you blind yourself to users. To arbitrarily throw away contrast based on a fashion that “looks good on my perfect screen in my perfectly lit office” is abdicating designers’ responsibilities to the very people for whom they are designing.
